descriptions:

Part A: Describe one claim made in the source.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • While racial tension in Black literature most often culminates in violence, sometimes it develops into a deep appreciation of Blackness.

  • While conflicts related to race in Black literature often involve violence, at times they also include a celebration of Black culture.

  • The Black Arts movement was distinct from the works of the Négritude movement.

  • African American literature often celebrates Black culture.

  • Racial tension is a major theme of Black literature; in some literature, the separation caused by this tension is portrayed as a haven for Black people.

  • African American literature often addresses the stress caused by a racist society.

The response accomplishes the task set by part A of the question.

Part B: Describe a broader historical context of the source.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • The Black Arts movement existed within the Black Liberation and anti-colonial movements of the 1960s and 1970s.

  • The literature discussed in the source was authored in the 1960s and 1970s in the context of the Black Power movement, which focused on racial pride.

  • The Black Arts movement coincided with the Black is Beautiful movement as people began to express pride in their culture and projected these images in various art forms.

  • The literature discussed in the source was authored during a growing interest in studying Black history and culture on many college campuses in the 1960s and 1970s.

The response accomplishes the task set by part B of the question.

descriptions:

Part C: Using one specific example, explain how a development described in the source influenced Black culture.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • The celebration of Black identity discussed in the source reflects the Black is Beautiful movement, which embraced Black beauty and Afrocentricity.

  • The ideas of the Black Arts movement discussed in the source galvanized the work of Black artists, writers, musicians, and dramatists who envisioned art as a political tool to achieve Black liberation.

  • The ideas of the Black Arts movement addressed in the source provided a means of self-expression for African Americans that reflected standards established by Black people.

  • The Black Arts movement led to the production of new works of fine art, such as Negro es Bello II by Elizabeth Catlett, that reflected the political and social experiences of African Americans.

The response accomplishes the task set by part C of the question.

Part D: Briefly explain how a development described in the source influenced the development of African American Studies.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • The Black Arts movement inspired the creation of Black magazines, publishing houses, art houses, scholarly journals, and some of the earliest African American Studies programs in colleges and universities.

  • The flourishing of Black cultural forms described in the source helped to establish African American Studies as an interdisciplinary field.

  • The double-consciousness of African Americans as African and American would be reflected and explored within the interdisciplinary approach of African American Studies.

  • The literary exploration of race discussed in the source reflects the development of African American Studies as an interdisciplinary approach for understanding Black freedom struggles.

The response accomplishes the task set by part D of the question.
